summary.title: Threat Model for our e-Commerce System
summary.description: STRIDE-based threat model for the e-commerce application with clearly defined process boundaries for penetration testing

data.name: Internet Trust Boundary
data.description: External users accessing the system from the internet - untrusted zone

data.name: Application Trust Boundary
data.description: Protected backend services and databases - trusted internal zone

data.name: Customer
data.description: Authenticated customer using the e-commerce platform

threats.title: Customer Spoofing
threats.description: Provide a description for this threat. A customer could attempt to impersonate another registered customer to gain unauthorized access to their account or personal data.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce strong authentication (passwords, MFA)

Monitor unusual login activity

Lock accounts after multiple failed login attempts

threats.title: Customer Repudiation
threats.description: A customer could deny performing actions like placing an order or updating account details.
threats.mitigation:
Maintain tamper-proof audit logs

Timestamp all transactions

threats.title: Guest Spoofing
threats.description: A guest (unauthenticated user) could attempt to impersonate another user or manipulate session identifiers to gain unauthorized access to system functionality or view restricted information.
threats.mitigation:
- Validate all session tokens
- Rate-limit API requests
- Monitor unusual access patterns

threats.title: Guest Repudiation
threats.description: A guest could deny sending requests or accessing certain APIs, making it difficult to track malicious activity or abuse.
threats.mitigation:
Log all guest requests with IP, user agent, and timestamps

Use server-side request validation

Implement anomaly detection for unusual traffic

threats.title: Admin Spoofing
threats.description: An attacker could attempt to impersonate an admin to gain unauthorized access to backend functionality, modify critical data, or manage other users.
threats.mitigation:
- Enforce strong authentication (password + MFA)
- Restrict admin access via IP whitelisting
- Monitor and alert on suspicious admin logins
- Use role-based access controls to limit privileges

threats.title: Admin Repudiation
threats.description: An admin could deny performing actions such as modifying user accounts, updating products, or deleting orders, potentially hiding malicious or erroneous activities.
threats.mitigation:
- Maintain detailed audit logs with timestamps and user IDs
- Require digital signatures or confirmation for critical actions
- Implement immutable logging where possible

data.name: Auth Service
data.description: Authentication and authorization service - maps to auth controller/service

threats.title: Auth Service Spoofing: Impersonation of Users or Admins
threats.description: An attacker could attempt to log in as another user or admin by using stolen credentials, session tokens, or exploiting flaws in login mechanisms. Successful spoofing allows unauthorized access to protected areas, including the Customer Service, Order Service, Product Service, and Admin Service endpoints.
threats.mitigation:
Use strong password policies and secure password storage (hashing + salting).

Monitor login patterns and alert on anomalous activity.

Lock accounts temporarily after repeated failed login attempts.

threats.title: Auth Service Tampering: Modification of Authentication Requests or Responses
threats.description: An attacker could modify authentication traffic or payloads to bypass security controls, elevate privileges, or manipulate session data. Examples include changing JSON fields in API requests, replaying or altering JWT tokens, or tampering with login challenge responses.
threats.mitigation:
Use HTTPS for all communication to prevent in-transit tampering.

Validate all inputs server-side, including token and session data.

Implement integrity checks (e.g., HMAC for tokens).

Reject malformed or replayed requests.

threats.title: Auth Service Repudiation: Denial of Authentication Actions
threats.description: A user could deny having attempted a login, logged out, or performed other authentication-related actions. Without tamper-proof logging, it becomes difficult to verify whether authentication requests originated from the legitimate user or were malicious.
threats.mitigation: Maintain tamper-proof audit logs of authentication attempts, timestamp all actions.

threats.title: Auth Service Information Disclosure: Exposure of Credentials or Tokens
threats.description: An attacker could gain access to passwords, session tokens, or secret keys due to insecure storage, transmission, or verbose error messages. Exposure can lead to account takeover or unauthorized system access.
threats.mitigation:
Hash and salt all passwords before storage.

Encrypt tokens and sensitive authentication data at rest and in transit.

Limit error messages to avoid revealing whether a username or password was correct.

Rotate and expire tokens regularly.

threats.title: Auth Service Denial of Service: Disruption of Authentication endpoints
threats.description: Attackers may flood the authentication endpoints with repeated login attempts, API requests, or malformed payloads, preventing legitimate users from logging in and potentially impacting downstream services that rely on authentication.
threats.mitigation: Rate limiting, autoscaling, monitor traffic anomalies.

threats.title: Auth Service Elevation of Privilege: Privilege Escalation via Authentication Flaws
threats.description: An attacker could exploit weaknesses in the authentication logic such as predictable session tokens, improper role assignment, or bypassing login checks to escalate from a regular user account to an administrative account. This could allow the attacker to access all system data, modify other users’ accounts, and perform restricted admin operations.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce strict server-side role validation for every request

Securely generate, validate, and expire session tokens

Regularly review and patch authentication-related vulnerabilities

Implement least-privilege access controls and logging for all privilege changes

data.name: Customer Service
data.description: Customer profile and account management - maps to customer controller/service

threats.title: Customer Service Spoofing: Unauthorized Access via Customer Identity Spoofing
threats.description: An attacker could impersonate another customer by reusing stolen session tokens, forging authentication credentials, or manipulating cookies. This allows them to access or modify another customer’s account data, including profile information, addresses, and preferences.
threats.mitigation: Authentication tokens, session validation, access control checks.

threats.title: Customer Service Tampering: Unauthorized Modification of Customer Data
threats.description: An attacker could exploit weaknesses in the Customer Service API to alter customer profile data without authorization. This includes changing names, addresses, phone numbers, or account preferences. Vulnerabilities such as missing server‑side validation, insecure direct object references (IDOR), or weak session handling could allow modification of another user’s profile data.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce strict authorization (user can only modify their own profile)

Validate and sanitize all incoming profile update requests

Use non‑guessable customer identifiers internally

Maintain audit logs of all profile‑related changes

threats.title: Customer Service Repudiation: Denial of Customer Actions
threats.description: Customers could deny performing actions such as updating profiles or submitting orders. Without proper tracking, it becomes difficult to prove the legitimacy of customer actions, leading to potential disputes or financial loss.
threats.mitigation: Maintain immutable audit logs with timestamps, implement digital signatures for critical operations, and store logs securely for dispute resolution.

threats.title: Customer Service Information Disclosure: Unauthorized Access to Customer Personal Data
threats.description: Sensitive customer data including emails, addresses, phone numbers, payment details, and order history could be exposed due to insufficient access controls, insecure APIs, or unencrypted storage, leading to privacy breaches or identity theft.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce role-based access control (customers can only access their own data).

Encrypt sensitive data both at rest and in transit.

Audit and log all access to personal data.

Limit data returned in API responses to only necessary fields.

threats.title: Customer Service Denial of Service: Disruption of Customer Account Access
threats.description: Attackers could overwhelm customer service endpoints such as APIs, forms, or chat systems with excessive requests, causing slow response times or complete service outages, which prevents legitimate customers from accessing services.
threats.mitigation:
Implement rate limiting and request throttling per user/IP.

Use load balancing and autoscaling to handle legitimate traffic spikes.

Monitor traffic patterns and detect anomalies for early mitigation.

threats.title: Customer Service Elevation of Privilege: Unauthorized Access to Admin or Restricted Functions or Other Users
threats.description: An attacker could exploit flaws in the business logic of Customer Service such as missing authorization checks, insecure APIs, or predictable user identifiers to access or modify other customers’ data. For example, the attacker could change another user’s profile, view order history, or update personal information without permission.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce strict server-side authorization for every API call.

Implement ownership checks (users can only modify their own data).

Block guest access to any account-specific endpoints.

Conduct security-focused code reviews to identify logic flaws.

Log and monitor all sensitive operations.

data.name: Order Service
data.description: Order processing and management - maps to order controller/service

threats.title: Order Service Spoofing: Unauthorized Order Action via Identity Spoofing
threats.description: An attacker may attempt to impersonate another customer by submitting forged authentication tokens or replaying stolen session IDs to access the Order Service. Successful spoofing would allow the attacker to place orders using another user’s account, cancel legitimate orders, or retrieve order histories belonging to other customers.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce strict token validation (expiration, signature, issuer).

Implement session binding to device/IP where appropriate.

Detect and block session replay attempts.

threats.title: Order Service Tampering: Manipulation of Order Data and Transaction Values
threats.description: An attacker could intercept or forge requests to alter order attributes, such as product quantity, order totals, or applied discounts. Business logic flaws (e.g., client‑side price calculation, insecure state transitions, or IDOR) may enable attackers to reduce prices, change order status, or assign orders to a different customer.
threats.mitigation:
Perform all pricing and total calculations server-side.

Enforce strict order‑state validation (user cannot arbitrarily set “Paid,” “Shipped,” etc.).

Validate all request payloads for integrity.

Use non‑guessable order identifiers.

Apply HMAC or server-side recomputation for critical fields.

threats.title: Order Service Repudiation: Denial of Order-Related Actions
threats.description: A customer or attacker may deny having placed, updated, or canceled an order. Without tamper‑proof logging, the system cannot reliably prove whether an order action originated from the authenticated user, creating audit gaps and enabling fraudulent refund or cancellation claims.
threats.mitigation:
Implement append‑only, tamper-resistant audit logs.

Capture order events with timestamps, IP address, and hashed user identifiers.

Generate digital order confirmations and email receipts.

Use log integrity verification (e.g., hashing, chain-link logs).

threats.title: Order Service Information Disclosure: Exposure of Order Details and Customer Data
threats.description: Insufficient access control or insecure API design may expose order history, delivery addresses, payment references, or product lists belonging to other customers. This can occur via direct object reference attacks, verbose error messages, or insecure serialization of order objects.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce authorization checks on every order retrieval endpoint.

Encrypt sensitive fields (addresses, contact numbers, payment tokens).

Avoid returning unnecessary internal order attributes in API responses.

Log access to sensitive data for monitoring and forensics.

threats.title: Order Service Denial of Service: Disruption of Order Placement and Processing
threats.description: Attackers may flood the Order Service API with excessive order creation attempts, payment callbacks, or order‑status polling requests. This can overwhelm the service, resulting in legitimate customers being unable to place or complete orders, and may disrupt downstream services (payment provider, product inventory).
threats.mitigation:
Apply rate limiting on all high‑cost endpoints.

Implement request throttling and CAPTCHA for unauthenticated flows.

Use autoscaling for peak load protection.

Monitor for abnormal spikes in API usage and trigger alerts.

threats.title: Order Service Elevation of Privilege: Unauthorized Manipulation of Other Users’ Orders
threats.description: An attacker may exploit authorization flaws in the Order Service to access or alter orders belonging to other users, or perform privileged workflow actions such as marking an order as “Paid,” “Shipped,” or “Cancelled.” Logic flaws, missing ownership checks, and improper use of user IDs in the API can enable cross‑user order control or unauthorized escalation to admin-level operations.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce ownership validation for every order operation (requesting user must match order owner).

Restrict privileged actions (e.g., status transitions) to authorized roles.

Use server‑side authorization frameworks and avoid client‑based role hints.

Conduct security-focused code reviews for workflow logic.

data.name: Product Service
data.description: Product catalog and inventory management - maps to product controller/service

threats.title: Product Service Spoofing: Unauthorized Product Action via Identity Spoofing
threats.description: An attacker could impersonate an admin or authorized user by reusing stolen session tokens or forging authentication credentials. This could allow the attacker to create, modify, or delete product entries without proper authorization, potentially affecting pricing, stock, or product availability.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce MFA and strong authentication for admin users.

Validate all tokens server-side and bind sessions to device/IP.

Monitor login attempts and detect suspicious patterns.

threats.title: Product Service Tampering: Product Data Manipulation
threats.description: An attacker could tamper with product data in transit or at rest, such as prices, stock levels, or descriptions. This can occur through insecure APIs, lack of input validation, or client-side manipulation, enabling fraudulent price changes, inaccurate stock reporting, or misleading product descriptions.
threats.mitigation:
Validate all incoming requests server-side.

Enforce admin-level access controls for product modifications.

Use HTTPS and integrity checks for all API communications.

Maintain audit logs for all product changes.

threats.title: Product Service Repudiation: Denial of Product Modifications
threats.description: A malicious or careless admin could deny performing product-related actions (create, update, delete), making it difficult to verify accountability. Without tamper-proof logging, disputed changes could go untracked.
threats.mitigation:
Implement append-only audit logs with timestamps and user identifiers.

Use digital signatures for critical product updates.

Keep versioned records of product changes.

threats.title: Product Service Information Disclosure: Unauthorized Access to Product Data
threats.description: Flawed access control could allow attackers to view sensitive product information, including unpublished products, pricing, stock levels, or admin-only metadata. Exposure could lead to competitive leakage or inventory manipulation.
threats.mitigation:
Apply strict role-based access control for all endpoints.

Encrypt sensitive data at rest and in transit.

Log and monitor all product data accesses.

threats.title: Product Service Denial of Service: Disruption of Product Service Availability
threats.description: Attackers could flood product service endpoints (e.g., bulk product requests, update spam), rendering the catalog or admin interfaces unavailable. This impacts both customers browsing products and admins managing inventory.
threats.mitigation:
Apply rate limiting and throttling on high-cost endpoints.

Use autoscaling and load balancing to absorb spikes.

Detect and alert on abnormal traffic patterns.

threats.title: Product Service Elevation of Privilege: Unauthorized Product Modification via Logic Flaws
threats.description: An attacker could exploit business logic flaws or missing authorization checks to perform admin-only actions, such as altering product prices, stock levels, or visibility. Exploitation could allow non-admin users to manipulate critical product information.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce server-side authorization for all admin-level actions.

Validate user roles and session integrity for every request.

Conduct regular code reviews to identify and fix logic vulnerabilities.

Maintain audit trails of all privileged operations.

data.name: Admin Service
data.description: Administrative operations and management - maps to admin controller/service

threats.title: Admin Service Spoofing: Unauthorized Access via Admin Identity Spoofing
threats.description: An attacker may attempt to impersonate an admin account by replaying stolen tokens, forging cookies, or brute-forcing admin credentials. Successful impersonation grants full access to backend operations such as editing users, modifying products, adjusting orders, or accessing system dashboards.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce MFA for all admin accounts

Implement IP allowlists or VPN-gated access for admin portal

Bind sessions to device/IP and detect token anomalies

Monitor and alert on unusual admin login locations or patterns

threats.title: Admin Service Tampering: Unauthorized Modification of Administrative Data
threats.description: If authorization checks or API validation are weak, an attacker could alter critical backend data, such as changing product prices, editing order states, or injecting malicious configuration values. Such tampering can fully compromise the business workflow and data integrity.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce server-side validation for all admin actions

Protect admin endpoints with RBAC and least-privilege

Require confirmation for high-impact operations

Maintain immutable audit logs of administrative changes

threats.title: Admin Service Repudiation: Denial of Critical Administrative Actions
threats.description: An admin may deny performing actions such as changing user roles, deleting products, adjusting stock, or modifying order statuses. Without reliable logging and event attribution, malicious or accidental admin actions cannot be traced, creating gaps in accountability.
threats.mitigation:
Implement tamper-proof, append-only audit logs

Record timestamps, admin ID, IP, and action details

Use signed administrative actions or confirmation tokens

Store logs in a secure, isolated audit database

threats.title: Admin Service Information Disclosure: Exposure of Sensitive Administrative or System Data
threats.description: Weak access controls or overly permissive endpoints may leak internal administrative data, including user role mappings, system configuration, order summaries, unpublished product data, or operational dashboards. Such disclosure gives attackers insights to plan targeted attacks or manipulate system behavior.
threats.mitigation:
Restrict all admin endpoints to authorized roles only

Hide internal fields from API responses

Encrypt sensitive logs and configuration data

Monitor for suspicious access to admin-only resources

threats.title: Admin Service Denial of Service: Disruption of Administrative Operations
threats.description: Attackers may spam admin endpoints (e.g., product update, user search, role assignment) or trigger expensive backend operations to overwhelm the Admin Service. This prevents legitimate administrators from performing essential tasks such as updating catalogs, responding to incidents, or managing customer issues.
threats.mitigation:
Apply rate limiting to administrative APIs

Isolate admin workloads from public traffic

Monitor and alert on abnormal request spikes

Deploy redundancy and autoscaling for backend operations

data.name: Customer Database
data.description: Stores customer account information, credentials, and profiles

threats.title: Customer DB Tampering: Unauthorized Modification of Customer Data
threats.description: Attackers could modify or corrupt customer records, including profiles, addresses, contact information, or preferences, by exploiting weak database permissions, injection attacks, or unvalidated API input. Such tampering can lead to data integrity issues, incorrect order processing, or financial loss.
threats.mitigation:
Implement role-based access control (RBAC) and least-privilege permissions for database users.

Use parameterized queries or prepared statements to prevent injection attacks.

Validate all inputs on the server side and enforce strict schema validation.

Maintain versioned backups and implement database integrity checks.

threats.title: Customer Database Repudiation: Denial of Customer Data Changes
threats.description: Modifications to customer data could go untracked if audit logs are missing or tampered with, allowing attackers or insiders to deny having made changes. This prevents accountability and makes it difficult to investigate or resolve disputes.
threats.mitigation:
Implement append-only audit logs with timestamps, user IDs, and operation details.

Digitally sign critical updates to ensure tamper-evidence.

Store logs in a secure, isolated system separate from the main database.

Regularly monitor and verify log integrity.

threats.title: Customer Database Information Disclosure: Exposure of Sensitive Customer Data
threats.description: Unauthorized access could reveal sensitive customer information, such as emails, addresses, payment details, and purchase history. This can occur due to misconfigured permissions, insufficient encryption, or exploitation of vulnerabilities in APIs or database interfaces.
threats.mitigation:
Encrypt sensitive data at rest using industry-standard encryption (e.g., AES-256).

Use TLS/HTTPS for all database and API communications to secure data in transit.

Apply fine-grained access controls so only authorized services or personnel can access sensitive data.

Audit and log all access to sensitive fields and monitor for anomalous activity.

threats.title: Customer Database Denial of Service: Disruption of Customer Database Availability
threats.description: The database could be rendered unavailable by flooding queries, exploiting locking mechanisms, resource exhaustion, or triggering expensive operations. This can block legitimate customers from accessing accounts or placing orders.
threats.mitigation:
Implement rate limiting and throttling for API calls to the database.

Use connection pooling and query timeouts to protect resources.

Deploy replication and failover clusters to maintain availability.

Monitor database metrics (CPU, memory, query execution time) and alert on anomalies.

data.name: Admin Database
data.description: Stores admin user accounts and permissions

data.name: Product Data Response
data.description: Product catalog data response to customer

data.name: Guest Product Response
data.description: Product catalog data response to guest

data.name: Order Customer Query
data.description: Query customer data for order validation

data.name: Product Database
data.description: Stores product catalog, pricing, and inventory data

data.name: Order Database
data.description: Stores order transactions and order history

data.name: Audit Log Database
data.description: Stores audit logs from all services for security and compliance
